column3: The other co-owner of the ship Pequod. He is the exact opposite of Captain Peleg; he is cool in temperament, religious, and shrewd.

column2: Who is Bulkington?
column3: A quiet but dangerous sailor, whom Ishmael sees for the first time in the Spouter Inn. Later, Bulkington is Ishmael's shipmate on the whaling voyage.

column2: Who is Captain Ahab?
column3: The dark, brooding, peg-legged captain of the the whaling ship Pequod.  He wants to find and kill Moby Dick, the whale that caused him to lose his leg.

column2: Who is Captain Boomer?
column3: One-armed English whaling captain; master of the Samuel Enderby.

column2: Who is Captain Peleg?
column3: Retired whaleman of Nantucket. Former chief-mate and later co-owner of the ship Pequod. He is an imposing, short- tempered, and foul-mouthed man. Bildad and Peleg hire the crew.

column2: Who is Daggoo?
column3: Third harpooner on the Pequod; described as 'a gigantic, coal-black negro-savage'.

column2: Who is Elijah?
column3: Shabbily dressed street prophet in New Bedford; warns of Captain Ahab as 'Old Thunder'.

column2: Who is Father Mapple?
column3: The chaplain (in New Bedford) who gives a moving sermon based on the Biblical story of Jonah and the whale in the Whalemen's chapel.

column2: Who is Fedallah?
column3: Strange, 'oriental' old Parsee; Ahab's harpooner and personal prophet.

column2: Who is Flask?
column3: Third mate of the Pequod; from Martha's Vineyard.

column2: Who is Fleece?
column3: The old Negro cook on the ship. He has bad knees. Under Stubb's instructions, he preaches a sermon to the sharks hovering around the dead sperm whale which is tied to the ship's side.

column2: Who is Gabriel?
column3: The self-appointed prophet on the ship, Jeroboam. He believes himself to be the incarnation of the Shaker God and he warns all the crewmembers on board about Moby Dick, the White Whale.

column2: Who is Ishmael?
column3: The narrator of the novel and the only sailor to survive from the Pequod. He tells the entire story and actively participates in the drama that unfolds on Captain Ahab's whaling ship.

column2: Who is Mayhew?
column3: The captain of the Jeroboam, who had sighted and chased Moby Dick. Mayhew meets Ahab and tells him how the whale had killed his mate, Macey, during the chase.

column2: Who is Moby Dick?
column3: A giant and elusive white sperm whale. He serves as Captain Ahab's antagonist in the novel. Ahab's goal in life is to kill Moby Dick for having bitten off his leg.

column2: Who is Mrs. Hosea Hussey?
column3: The irate wife of the innkeeper at 'Try Pots' in Nantucket. In the innkeeper's absence, she runs the affairs of the inn efficiently.

column2: Who is Peter Coffin?
column3: The perhaps ironically named innkeeper of the Spouter Inn at New Bedford.

column2: Who is Pip?
column3: The cabin boy on the Pequod. He is a young Negro who is nervous and quiet by temperament and suffers a mental breakdown when left in the ocean for awhile. He becomes half idiot-half prophet.

column2: Who is Queequeg?
column3: A native of Kokovoko in the Fiji islands and an expert harpooner, who becomes Ishmael's friend and crewmate. Queequeg dies when the ship sinks.

column2: Who is Radney?
column3: The wicked and unjust mate on the Town-Ho. He is punished as though by divine providence when Moby Dick kills him.

column2: Who is Starbuck?
column3: A Quaker from Nantucket who serves as the first mate to the captain on the Pequod. An intelligent and brave officer, he lives his life by Christian principles.

column2: Who is Steel Kit?
column3: The popular sailor on Town-Ho who leads a mutiny on board. He makes secret plans to kill Radney, the most hated mate on the Town-Ho.

column2: Who is Stubb?
column3: Second mate of the Pequod; from Cape Cod.

column2: What about Captain Ahab?
column3: The dark, brooding, peg-legged captain of the ship, the Pequod. He is obsessed with finding and killing Moby Dick.

column2: What about Captain Boomer?
column3: He is a one-armed English whaling captain; master of the Samuel Enderby.

column2: Who is the subject of Father Mapple's sermon?
What about Bildad's partner Captain Peleg?
column3: He is a retired whaleman of Nantucket, former chief-mate and later co-owner of the ship Pequod.

column2: What does Ahab keep destroying, one piece at a time, over the course of the voyage?
Who is Daggoo?
column3: Third harpooner on the Pequod; described as 'a gigantic, coal-black negro-savage'.

column2: Who is Elijah?
column3: Shabbily dressed street prophet in New Bedford; warns of Captain Ahab as 'Old Thunder'.

column2: Who is Father Mapple?
column3: The chaplain (in New Bedford) who gives a moving sermon based on the Biblical story of Jonah and the whale in the Whalemen's chapel.

column2: What about that Fedallah?
column3: He is a strange, 'oriental' old Parsee; Ahab's harpooner and personal prophet.

column2: What about the one called Flask?
column3: Flask is the third mate of the Pequod; from Martha's Vineyard.

column2: What about Fleece?
column3: He is the old Negro cook on the ship. Under Stubb's instructions, he preaches a sermon to the sharks hovering around the dead sperm whale, tied to the ship's side.

column2: What about Gabriel?
column3: He is a self-styled prophet on the Jeroboam. Believing himself to be the Shaker God incarnate, he influences all on board with his warnings about the White Whale.

column2: What about that Ishmael?
column3: He is the novel's narrator and the only sailor to survive from Captain Ahab's whaling ship, the Pequod.

column2: What about Mayhew?
column3: He is the captain of the Jeroboam, who had sighted and chased Moby Dick. Mayhew tells Ahab how the whale had killed his mate, Macey, during the chase.

column2: Of the three mates aboard the Pequod, which one was from Nantucket?
column3: Starbuck the first mate was a Nantucket Quaker.

column2: With what is the Pequod adorned?
What about Moby Dick?
column3: Moby Dick is a giant and elusive white sperm whale who serves as Captain Ahab's antagonist in the novel. Ahab's sworn purpose in life is to kill Moby Dick.

column2: What about Mrs. Hosea Hussey?
column3: She is the wife of the innkeeper at 'Try Pots' Inn, Nantucket, who runs the affairs of the inn efficiently when her husband is away.

column2: What about the one called Peter Coffin?
column3: He is the deathly-named innkeeper of the Spouter Inn at New Bedford.

column2: What about Pip?
column3: He is the Pequod's cabin boy, a nervous young Negro who loses his mind when he has been left in the sea awhile. He becomes half idiot-half prophet.

column2: What about the one named Queequeg?
column3: He is a native of Kokovoko in the Fiji islands and an expert harpooner, and despite his religion and customs, he is develops a bond with Ishmael.

column2: What about Radney?
column3: He is the wicked and unjust mate on the Town-Ho, punished as though by divine providence when Moby Dick kills him.

column2: What about Starbuck?
column3: He is a Nantucket Quaker serving as the first mate to the captain on the Pequod. He is intelligent and brave, and he lives according to Christian principles.

column2: What about Steel Kit?
column3: He is a popular sailor who leads a mutiny onboard the Town-Ho. He secretly plans to kill Radney, the most hated mate on the Town-Ho.

column2: What about the one named Stubb?
column3: He was the second mate of the Pequod, from Cape Cod.
